sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Secondary prostatic neoplasms are usually the result of direct invasion by neighboring organs or infiltration from hematological malignancies. Gastric adenocarcinoma metastasizing in the prostate is extremely rare and to our knowledge only seven cases have been documented in the literature. We report another case of a patient who underwent transurethral resection of prostate (TURP) for bladder outflow obstruction which incidentally revealed an occult metastatic adenocarcinoma from an undiagnosed gastric cancer.

sec.title: Case report
sec.p: A 67 year old man presented with refractory retention of urine. Two years prior to his urological presentation he complained of mild dyspepsia and was diagnosed to have gastritis by oesophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGD) and biopsy. On admission he did not complain of any gastrointestinal tract (GIT) symptoms. Physical examination was normal except for suprapubic tenderness, a palpable bladder and moderate prostatic enlargement of normal consistency.

Routine laboratory studies including the serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) and abdominal ultrasound were normal. TURP was performed and the histopathological specimen revealed foci of adenocarcinoma showing small tubular glands infiltrating the prostatic stroma. The immunohistochemical study was negative for PSA and positive for CK7 suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the upper gastrointestinal tract (Figure 1). In view of the previous history of gastritis and histopathological findings, OGD was repeated in which an antral gastric tumor was diagnosed. The biopsy demonstrated moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (Figure 2). Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan revealed irregular thickening of the stomach wall at the lesser sac extending into the antrum (Figure 3). The radiological staging including isotope bone scan did not detect any other secondary metastasis. Partial distal gastrectomy was performed. The patient remained asymptomatic for three years and follow up with regular abdominal CT scans have not revealed tumor recurrence.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Secondary prostatic neoplasms usually occur by direct invasion of adjacent tumors or infiltration from hematological neoplasia. Metastases from nonadjacent organs occur but are rare and often diagnosed at autopsies.1,2,3 Secondary prostatic metastases from gastric adenocarcinoma are exceedingly rare and to our knowledge only seven cases have been reported in the literature.3,4 In all previous cases the patients were already diagnosed to have gastric cancer and presented with lower urinary tract symptoms 2–14 years later. As for our patient the diagnosis of gastric malignancy was made because of an incidental finding of adenocarcinoma in the prostatic tissue with immunohistochemical studies suggestive of an upper GIT origin. In conclusion, gastric malignancy metastasizing to the prostate is a very rare event. Clinicians should be aware of this condition which will direct their attention to search for a gastric neoplasm and reduce the risk of missing a crucial diagnosis.
